Ni based catalyst performs high activity in methane dry reforming reaction but suffers from severe carbon deposition and deactivation. A series of CeO2 supported Ni catalysts promoted with various amounts of Ga were synthesized, and regulated the basic site of the catalysts. The Ni/CeO2 catalyst with 3 wt% Ga-doped shows the highest activity (XCH4 = 74% and XCO2 = 88%) and stability with the H2/CO ratio of 0.94 after a 35-h reaction without any carbon deposition. The CH4-CO2-CH4 pulse experiments indicate that the doping of Ga can produce enough oxygen species to eliminate the carbon deposition and maintain the catalytic activity. Superior activity with the better stability can be attributed to the enhanced CO2 adsorption and activation over the basic site of the catalyst, which is regulated by the introduction of Ga. These results provide a fundamental understanding of the relationship between the basic site regulated by Ga and the catalyst stability the Ni/CeO2 catalytic system. Graphical Abstract The doping of Ga successfully regulated the basicity of the Ni/CeO2 catalyst, promoted the adsorption and activation of CO2, which improved the catalytic activity and stability. Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 adsorption Basic site regulation Ga-promoted Ni/CeO2 Methane dry reforming Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Global climate change induced by greenhouse gases has been widely concerned in recent years [1]. The conversion of CO2 to fuels and chemicals is vital for alleviating the greenhouse effect [2,3]. Methane dry reforming (DRM) can convert two greenhouse gases (CH4 / CO2) into valuable syngas (H2 + CO) [4–6], and the product ratio is about 1, which can be directly applicable to Fischer-Tropsch synthesis to produce high value-added chemical products [7–10]. Ni-based catalysts with low cost and high activity have been extensively studied for DRM [5,8,11-17]. However, due to the serious coking and sintering problems the elevated temperature, it has not been applied in industry at present. Some studies have demonstrated that the side reactions were main factors [4,18], such as the complete decomposition of methane (Eq. 1), the disproportionation of CO (Eq. 2). Therefore, it is necessary to develop an efficient catalyst to resist sintering and coking. (1) CH4 → C + 2H2 ΔH° = + 75 kJ mol–1 (2) 2CO ↔ C + CO2 ΔH° = - 172 kJ mol–1 Using basic support, such as La2O3 [3,19], Al2O3 [20–22], MgO [9], ZrO2 [23,24] or CeO2 [25–28] can be considered as the effective way to overcome this problem. CeO2 is generally applied as catalyst support for DRM reaction because of the redox property [29–33]. Some researchers have been made extensive efforts to alter the catalyst via promoters [5,22,33-36]. Generally, promoters reduce the carbon deposition through the following ways: i), improve the adsorption and activation capacity of CO2 by regulate the basicity of catalyst. ii) increase the dispersion of nickel particles [11]. Even if the particle size of Ni is small, the surface carbon formed by the dissociation reaction of CH4 will continue to diffuse and grow, leading to the deactivation of catalyst. Therefore, it is important to eliminates carbon deposition in DRM. Typically, carbon deposition was formed from CH4 dissociation, while CO2 activation is important to the coke removal [37–39]. Ga is known to change the acidity of the catalyst [15]. It has been proved that it is feasible to combine Ga (III) cations into the Ce lattice, which has a great effect on the redox and acid-base properties of the Ce-Ga system [40]. In addition, Ga can promote inhibiting carbon deposition, because Ga can improve the ability of absorb CO2 [41–43]. So far, the impact of Ga doped Ni/CeO2 catalytic system on DRM has not been discussed. In this work, we synthesized and improved the number of basic sites of the Ni/CeO2 catalysts successfully by adding various amounts of Ga. We concerned the effects of the basic sites on CO2 activation, studied systematically the effect of basic sites on the catalytic stability, using more characterizations techniques. We provide an insight into the anti-coke mechanism of DRM over the Ga-doped Ni/CeO2 catalyst, these results provide a fundamental understanding of the relevant anti-coking effect of Ga on Ni-based catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst Preparation The synthesis method of CeO2 nano-rod followed the reference [44]. Typically, 1.96 g Ce(NO3)3⋅6H2O and 16.88 g NaOH were dissolved in 40 mL and 30 mL deionized water (DI), respectively. Then, the Ce(NO3)3 solution was dropped into the NaOH solution under stirring. The mixture was moved into the 100 mL Teflon bottle after stirred for 30 min. Followed by hydrothermal treatment at 100°C for 24 h. The sample was centrifugated and washed with DI water and ethanol for three times, and then dried at 80°C for 12 h. Finally, the as-prepared sample was calcined at 500°C for 2 h. The obtained powder was named “CeO2 nano-rod”. The loading weight of Ni on all samples was maintain 5 wt% while Ga was introduced by the impregnation method with the loading weight of 0.0, 1.0, 3.0, and 5.0 wt%. The sample was named as Ni/xGa-CeO2, and x represents loading weight of Ga. A desirable amount of precursor, including GaCl3, Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O or both, was dissolved in 1 mL of DI water and was mixed by ultrasonic treatment for 5 min. Then the precursor solution was added into the CeO2 nano-rod powder, and aging for 2 h. The sample was dried at 80°C for 12 h and was calcined at 500°C for 2 h. Ni/CeO2 and Ga-CeO2 catalysts were prepared via the same procedures with the loading weight of 5 wt% for Ni and Ga, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The specific surface area and pore volume measurements were performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020. Hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), H2 temperature programmed desorption (H2-TPD), and carbon dioxide temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) measurements were performed on a Micrometric AutoChem 2950. In the H2-TPR analysis, about 0.1 g of the sample was pretreated in Ar at 300°C for 30 min to remove the impurities. The sample was heated from 50 to 700°C under the 10% H2/Ar as the reductant after cooled down to 50°C. Prior to CO2-TPD and H2-TPD experiments, 0.1 g of the sample was reduced in 10% H2/Ar at 600°C for 1 h. The gas of adsorbate (CO2 or H2, 50 mL min–1) was introduced for 1 h after cooling down to 50°C. Subsequently, the sample was purged with flowing He to remove the physically adsorbed CO2 or H2. Then the sample was heated to 700°C. The dispersion was calculated by the H2 desorption amount of H2-TPD. The temperature-programmed surface reaction (CH4/CO2-TPSR) and oxygen temperature programmed oxidation (O2-TPO) measurements were carried out using a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2950 instrument connecting with on-line mass spectrum (Hiden Analytical HA), continuously monitoring the signals of H2 (m/e = 2), CH4 (m/e = 16), CO (m/e = 28), H2O (m/e = 18) and CO2 (m/e = 44). 0.1 g of the sample was reduced in 10% H2/Ar at 600°C for 1 h and then cooled down to 50°C under flowing He (50 mL min–1). The reactant gas CH4, CO2 or O2 with 50 mL min–1 was introduced into the sample with the temperature ramped to 800°C. Continuous pulse experiments were also conducted on the same system. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of materials were acquired by an Empyrean instrument with Cu Kα radiation (λ =0.1541 nm, 45 kV, 40 mA) in a scan range from 10° to 90°. The surface electronic states were determined by X-ray photo electron spectroscopy (XPS) on a Thermo Fischer with Al Kα = 1486.6 eV. The signal of O 1s, C 1s, Ce 3d regions were recorded. The morphology of the sample was observed using the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) on an FEI TalosF200S. Before measurement, dissolve the sample in ethanol and ultrasound for 30 min, then dropped onto copper grid. The Raman spectra was collected using a LabRAM HR Evolution with excitation at 532 nm for the spent catalysts to observe changes of carbon species. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, NETZSCH STA 409 PC apparatus) was applied to measure the mass ratio of carbon in the spent catalyst. In situ DRIFTS experiment were measured using a Bruker INVENIO S FTIR spectrometer. The catalyst was reduced with 10% H2/Ar flow at 600°C for 1 h. The experiment was performed using CO2 at 50°C (30 mL min –1). 2.3 Dry reforming test The catalytic tests were performed in fixed-bed reactor with an inner diameter of 8 mm under atmospheric pressure. A cold trap with ice was placed between the reactor outlet and the inlet of gas chromatograph to remove the water during the reaction. Firstly, 50 mg of catalyst was reduced under 10% H2/Ar at 600°C for 1 h. Afterwards, Ar (50 mL·min–1) was used to purge the residual H2 for 20 min at 600°C. Then, heat up to 800°C, and introduced the feed gas mixture (CH4: CO2: Ar = 1:1:2) into the reactor with a total GHSV of 48 L h–1 g–1. 3 Results & discussion 3.1 Fresh catalyst characterization TEM images of all catalysts show similar nanorod structures, and the elemental mapping images confirm that the supported Ni nanoparticles are well dispersed over the catalysts (Fig. 1 a-c and Fig. S1). Furthermore, the Ga-doped catalysts maintained the mesopore structure, which is confirmed by N2 physisorption (Fig. S2a-b). The addition of Ga has a positive effect on Ni dispersion and BET surface area (Table S1). The diffraction peaks of all catalysts are similar to the cube structure of CeO2 (JCPDS: 34-0394) (Fig. 1f). NiO signal was not observed by XRD, indicating the particle size of Ni is too small to be identified [8]. The shift of CeO2(111) of Ni/xGa-CeO2 samples can be attributed to the modified Ni-CeO2 interaction induced by the addition of Ga. The addition of various amounts of Ga did not lead to the formation of any new phases, but the intensity of the CeO2 peaks were changed, indicating that the particle size was changed by Ga doped [45]. These results show that the doping of Ga has no obvious effect on the morphological and textural properties of CeO2. H2-TPR experiment is used to determine the interaction between metal and support. Peaks of catalysts are centered at 228, 317, and 611°C (Fig. S2d), corresponding to the reduction of bulk NiO species, NiO species with weak interaction, and NiO species with strong interaction, respectively [46,47]. The temperature of peaks on the Ga-doped catalysts is higher than the Ni/CeO2 catalyst, confirming an enhanced interaction by doping Ga. To investigate the oxygen vacancies of all the catalysts, Raman experiment was conducted. The Raman peaks at 462 cm–1, 592 cm–1, and 1174 cm–1, were ascribed to the F2g symmetry mode, defect induced mode (D bond), and seconded-order longitudinal optical mode (2LO bond) [6,10,48,49] (Fig. S3). The relative intensity ratio of I D/IF2g represented the concentration of oxygen vacancy in ceria [10,50]. It is shown that there are similar amounts of oxygen vacancies in the catalysts. Generally, the strength of basic sites is categorized as weak, medium, and strong at the temperature ranges < 200°C, 200-400°C, and 400-700°C. Fig. 2 a-b show the results of CO2-TPD experiments of the catalysts. The desorption peaks shifted towards higher temperatures with the increasing amount of Ga. As shown in Fig. 2c, the introduction of Ga significantly enhances the CO2 adsorption. Particularly, the Ni/3Ga-CeO2 catalyst exhibits the highest weak-medium basic sites concentration. Which is favorable for CO2 adsorption and activation [51]. Therefore, the coking-resist ability of catalyst is improved. The effect of doping of Ga in DRM reaction was studied by CH4-TPSR (Fig. 3 a-b) and CO2-TPSR (Fig. 3c-d). CH4-TPSR was used to test the CH4 activation ability of the catalysts. The CH4 consumption of the Ga-doped catalysts is more than the Ni/CeO2 catalyst, indicating that Ga plays a promoting role in CH4 dissociation (Fig. 3a). This could be attributed to the promotion of Ga doping dispersion of Ni. H2 generation is attributed to the dissociation of CH4 [52] (Fig. 3b). The performance of the catalyst is related to not only CH4 activation but also the oxidation of generated carbon species generated. Herein, CO2 activation is a critical process in DRM reaction [53], and the O* can oxidize CHx*. As the results of CO2-TPSR, the Ga-doped catalysts show the higher CO amount, indicating the promotion Ga on CO2 activation [9] (Fig. 3c). However, the Ni/5Ga-CeO2 catalyst only produced a small amount of CO, which may be because of the strong basic sites, which can adsorb CO2 and with high stability. In addition, enough O* was dissociated by CO2 and reacted with H2 (Fig. S4), which is verified by the production of H2O (Fig. 3d). The Ga-doped catalysts played a positive role in CH4 dissociation and CO2 activation. Ga doped catalysts are expected to show a better performance in coke resistance. 3.2 Catalytic performance for DRM 3.2.1 Activity tests The catalytic activity was explored at different temperatures under the same conditions for Ni/3Ga-CeO2 catalyst (Fig. S5), the higher reaction temperature always cause higher activity because of the endothermic nature. At 850°C, the reaction reached near-equilibrium conversions (XCH4 = 90% and XCO2 = 95%). The Ga-CeO2 sample without Ni for comparison showed no conversions at 800°C, suggesting Ga has no catalytic activity for this reaction (Fig. 4 a-b). It is evident that Ga-doped Ni catalysts showed higher activity and good stability except for Ni/5Ga-CeO2 (Fig. 4a-b). It is clear that the Ga promoter improved the H2/CO ratio from 0.84 to 0.93 with the addition of 3 wt% Ga (Fig. 4c). The Ni/3Ga-CeO2 catalyst show a higher conversion of CO2 of 88% and without deactivation after a 35-h reaction. But the decreasing activity for the Ni/CeO2 catalyst due to the serious carbon deposition. In addition, the conversions of CO2 are higher than the CH4 conversion since CO2 reacts with the produced H2 to form H2O. We also investigated the effect of GHSV on activity over the Ni/3Ga-CeO2 catalyst. At the GHSV of 24 L h–1 g–1, the catalyst shows obviously better performance compared to the higher GHSV (Fig. S6), the conversions of CH4 and CO2 and the corresponding H2/CO recorded are approximately 86%, 95%, and 0.98 respectively. This is corresponded to a longer residence time, which allows sufficient time to oxidize carbon, and reduces carbon deposition as well. In addition, higher conversions can be ascribed to the longer contact times between reactants and catalysts. The catalyst also showed good stability at the high GHSV, which proved the Ga-doped catalyst has an enhanced carbon deposition resistance. The Ni/3Ga-CeO2 catalyst treated at different reduction temperatures were also applied for DRM, and exhibit similar activity and stability (Fig. S7). Therefore, different Ni valence states are not the main reason affecting the stability of the reaction in the catalytic system [53]. The effect of operating temperature on the equilibrium state is shown in Fig. S8 under the pressure of 1 atm. The conversions of CH4 and CO2 are increased with the increasing temperature. The ratio of H2/CO shows the similar trend as well. As shown in Fig. 4, the CH4 and CO2 conversions are below equilibrium conversion. 3.2.2 Spent catalyst characterization The spent catalysts after the DRM reaction for 35 h were examined by TEM, TGA, and Raman to analyze the carbon deposition. The formation of carbon nanotubes and bulk sintering can be seen on the Ni/CeO2 catalyst as shown in Fig. 5 a-c, which is the main factor for the catalyst deactivation. However, the Ni/3Ga-CeO2 catalyst retained its initial structure (Fig. 5g), and no severe carbon deposition is observed (Fig. 5d). This indicates the better resistance of carbon‐deposition. More importantly, the particle size of the catalyst increases due to sintering after high temperature treatment, although the nickel nanoparticles of the Ni/3Ga-CeO2 catalyst grow, they are not large enough to form deposited carbon (Fig. 5e-h), as confirmed by TG and Raman analysis. The results of TG analysis further confirm that no carbon deposition formed on the Ga-doped catalysts after 35 h of stability testing (Fig. 6 a). However, obvious mass losses on the Ni/CeO2 catalyst (40 wt%) are detected. The evolution signals of CO2 in the O2-TPO experiment due to the oxidation of carbon deposition (Fig. 6c). In addition, Raman spectra were used to analyze the graphitic degree [54]. Both graphite band (G-band) at 1575 cm–1 and defect band (D-band) at 1340 cm–1 can be seen over the spent Ni/CeO2 catalyst (Fig. 6b). The distinctly strong intensity of the G band (I D/I G = 0.81), indicating that the graphite carbon was formed easily over the Ni/CeO2 catalyst, which is difficult to remove [55]. However, there is no carbon peak on the spent Ga-doped catalysts, which is consistent with the above discussions. The improved stability of Ga-doped catalysts is achieved by inhibiting the formation of graphite carbon. Compared to the fresh catalysts the pore diameter of the spent catalysts and their BJH pore volume (Table S1, Fig. S9) are decreased after reacting at 800°C for 35 h due to the sintering induced by elevated temperature. 3.2.3 DRM mechanism of Ni/xGa-CeO2 The in situ CO2 adsorption experiments were used to further verify the effects of Ga on the formation of surface carbonates. The vibrational bands at 1640, 1590, 1520 and 1340 cm–1 are characteristic of bicarbonate, formate, carbonates and bidentate carbonates (Fig. 7 ) [52,56,57], respectively. Moreover, the adsorbed bands of active formate species on the Ni/3Ga-CeO2 catalyst showed the strongest intensity, while for Ni/5Ga-CeO2 only appeared some strong chemical adsorption belonged to monodentate and bidentate carbonates, whereas the monodentate and bidentate carbonates are inactive for coke elimination [58]. Furthermore, the blue shift (from 1580 to 1590 cm−1) of formate species on the Ni/3Ga-CeO2 catalyst results from more stable CO2 adsorption. The CO2 adsorption on Ga-doped catalyst is increased compared with Ni/CeO2 due to the modification of CeO2. This result clearly indicates that the doping of Ga to Ni/CeO2 catalytic system enhances the basicity of catalyst leading to the enhanced activation of CO2 [59,60]. To demonstrate the role of Ga on CO2 adsorption and activation, a CH4-CO2-CH4 pulses experiment was conducted in the quartz tube reactor connected to MS. Compare with the CH4/CO2-TPSR experiments, the reaction gas exposure to the catalyst is short and with a smaller amount each needle in the pulsed experiment. As shown in Fig. 8 , CH4 and CO2 were introduced with fixed volume (0.5 mL) in order CH4 (#1-11) → CO2 (#12-14) → CH4 (#15-16) under continuous He flow. The reaction temperature was retained at 800°C. When CH4 is pulsed on the reduced catalyst, the formation of H2, and CO are observed, suggesting that CH4 is dissociated to form H2, and C-containing intermediates as well as these carbonaceous intermediates are oxidized by oxygen species produce CO. It is observed the consumption of CH4 decreases with a concurrently decrease in CO formation over subsequent pulses of CH4 (Fig. 8a). This decreasing activity is derived from the coverage of Ni active sites, and the oxygen species is insufficient to oxidation of carbon deposition. In situ catalyst regeneration was investigated by introducing CO2 (#12-14), the CO2 pulse is expected to eliminate the carbon deposition. The evolution signals of CO result from the dissociation of CO2 and the oxidation of coke. Moreover, the Ga-doped catalysts exhibit the higher CO signals, indicating the positive effect of Ga on CO2 adsorption and activation. In the subsequent CH4 pulse (#15-16), an obviously increased CH4 conversion and higher H2 generation are observed. This indicates that CO2 oxidizes the carbon deposition to release the active sites. Carbon deposition was more severe on the non-Ga doped Ni/CeO2 catalyst because of the inadequate oxygen species, that are unable to eliminate the coke derived from CH4 dissociation. Fig. S10 shows the different amounts of carbon accumulation during the pulse. However, the carbon decreased during continuous pulse on the Ga-doped catalysts, which effectively prove the interstitial carbon rapidly converting into CO to suppress its conversion to the coke, thus improving the stability of the Ga-doped catalysts. CH4 and CO2 activation during DRM follow different routes. As shown in Fig. 9 , the CH4 adsorbed on the supported Ni NPs is dissociated firstly to CHx* (x = 0-3) intermediate and while CO2 was dissociated on the support surface to produce CO* and O* species. Then CHx* species can react with the O* species to form the formate intermediates to produce CO and H2 [59,60]. The Ga-doped CeO2 support catalyst improves the basic site of the support, which contributes more effectively to CO2 adsorption and activation, and more O* species production helps to improve the coking-resist ability of the catalyst [41]. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we investigated the effects of basic sites on the coke-resistance ability of the Ni/CeO2 catalyst by doping various amounts of Ga (1.0, 3.0, and 5.0 wt%). The result of experiments proved that Ga doping did not cause obvious changes on the morphology of the Ni/CeO2 catalyst but improve the amount of basic sites and Ni dispersion. Particularly, the addition of 3 wt% Ga leads to the highest concentration of medium basic site, while the excessive Ga (5 wt%) induces the formation of strong basic sites which in turn weaken the activation of CO2. The CO2 conversion of 88% with the H2/CO ratio of 0.94 were achieved on the Ni/3Ga-CeO2 catalyst, which also possesses the best stability after 35 h of reaction time among all the Ga-promoted catalysts. The improved stability is achieved by the promotion of coke removal caused by the introduction of Ga. This work gives insights into the regulation of basic site over the Ni/CeO2 catalytic system. coredata.dc:description: Ni based catalyst performs high activity in methane dry reforming reaction but suffers from severe carbon deposition and deactivation. A series of CeO2 supported Ni catalysts promoted with various amounts of Ga were synthesized, and regulated the basic site of the catalysts. The Ni/CeO2 catalyst with 3 wt% Ga-doped shows the highest activity (XCH4 = 74% and XCO2 = 88%) and stability with the H2/CO ratio of 0.94 after a 35-h reaction without any carbon deposition. The CH4-CO2-CH4 pulse experiments indicate that the doping of Ga can produce enough oxygen species to eliminate the carbon deposition and maintain the catalytic activity. Superior activity with the better stability can be attributed to the enhanced CO2 adsorption and activation over the basic site of the catalyst, which is regulated by the introduction of Ga. These results provide a fundamental understanding of the relationship between the basic site regulated by Ga and the catalyst stability the Ni/CeO2 catalytic system.
coredata.dc:title: The Ga-promoted Ni/CeO2 catalysts for dry reforming of methane with high stability induced by the enhanced CO2 activation
